title: David Hillhouse Buel (soldier)
text:
David Hillhouse Buel (September 19, 1839 – July 22, 1870) was a <a href="United%20States%20Army">United States Army</a> officer who rose to the rank of <a href="Brevet%20%28military%29">brevet</a> <a href="Major%20%28United%20States%29">major</a> and <a href="Lieutenant%20colonel%20%28United%20States%29">lieutenant colonel</a> in the <a href="Union%20Army">Union Army</a> during the <a href="American%20Civil%20War">American Civil War</a>. Born in Michigan, he attended the United States Military Academy, and eventually became <a href="Ordnance%20Corps%20%28United%20States%20Army%29">Chief of Ordnance</a> of the <a href="Army%20of%20the%20Tennessee">Army of the Tennessee</a> and fought in the <a href="First%20Battle%20of%20Bull%20Run">First Battle of Bull Run</a>. He was killed by a soldier at <a href="Fort%20Leavenworth">Fort Leavenworth</a>, whom he had imprisoned for <a href="desertion">desertion</a>.
Early life.
David Hillhouse Buel was born on September 19, 1839, in <a href="Marshall%2C%20Michigan">Marshall, Michigan</a> to Samuel Buel and Jane Buel "née" Wilmer. He enrolled as a <a href="cadet">cadet</a> at the <a href="United%20States%20Military%20Academy">United States Military Academy</a> in <a href="West%20Point%2C%20New%20York">West Point, New York</a> on September 1, 1857, graduating on June 24, 1861.
He married Josephine Maria McDougal on September 28, 1861 in <a href="Poughkeepsie%2C%20New%20York">Poughkeepsie, New York</a>. His father presided over the marriage ceremony. McDougal was born on June 16, 1839 in <a href="Indianapolis">Indianapolis, Indiana</a>, and was the daughter of Brigadier General <a href="Charles%20McDougall%20%28United%20States%20Army%29">Charles McDougall</a>, a surgeon in the Army. Buel had two children. His daughter, Josephine Maria Buel, was born on February 13, 1866; she later changed her name to Violet McDougal. His son, <a href="David%20Hillhouse%20Buel%20%28priest%29">David Hillhouse Buel</a>, was born on June 19, 1862, and became a <a href="Society%20of%20Jesus">Jesuit</a> priest and the <a href="List%20of%20presidents%20of%20Georgetown%20University">president of Georgetown University</a>, before converting and becoming an <a href="Episcopal%20Church%20%28United%20States%29">Episcopal</a> minister.
Military career.
Buel served in the <a href="Union%20Army">Union Army</a> during the <a href="American%20Civil%20War">Civil War</a>. He was appointed the <a href="commanding%20officer">commanding officer</a> of the <a href="Kennebec%20Arsenal">Kennebec Arsenal</a> in <a href="Augusta%2C%20Maine">Augusta, Maine</a>, before becoming the commanding officer of the Leavenworth Arsenal at <a href="Fort%20Leavenworth">Fort Leavenworth</a> in <a href="Kansas">Kansas</a>. He became <a href="Ordnance%20Corps%20%28United%20States%20Army%29">Chief of Ordnance</a> of the <a href="Army%20of%20the%20Tennessee">Army of the Tennessee</a>. He was a <a href="Brevet%20%28military%29">brevetted</a> <a href="Major%20%28United%20States%29">major</a> and later <a href="Lieutenant%20colonel%20%28United%20States%29">lieutenant colonel</a> in the Ordnance Corps.
On July 22, 1870, Buel attended a party at the house of Brigadier General <a href="Samuel%20D.%20Sturgis">Samuel D. Sturgis</a>. While exiting his carriage in which he was returned from the party, he was shot and killed by a soldier, whom he had imprisoned in the guardhouse for <a href="desertion">desertion</a>. His widow married Buel's uncle, Oliver Prince Buel, on December 1, 1875, at <a href="Jefferson%20Barracks%20Military%20Post">Jefferson Barracks</a> in <a href="Missouri">Missouri</a>.
